abstract: I have so many programs on my PC that it takes me forever to find them in the Windows XP All Programs menu. Is there a way to customize the order they appear?
snippet: I have so many programs on my PC that it takes me forever to find them in the Windows XP All Programs menu. Is there a way to customize the order they appear?
lead_paragraph: Q. I have so many programs on my PC that it takes me forever to find them in the Windows XP All Programs menu. Is there a way to customize the order they appear?

abstract: I want to insert a QuickTime video clip into a PowerPoint file, but the format doesn’t work with my version of PowerPoint for Windows. Is there a way to make this work?
snippet: I want to insert a QuickTime video clip into a PowerPoint file, but the format doesn’t work with my version of PowerPoint for Windows. Is there a way to make this work?
lead_paragraph: Q. I want to insert a video clip that I took with my digital camera into a PowerPoint file. The movie is in the QuickTime format, which doesn’t work with my version of PowerPoint for Windows. Is there a way to make this work?

abstract: You can save paper by going to Word’s Print Preview in the File menu and clicking the “Shrink to Fit” or “Shrink One Page” button.
snippet: You can save paper by going to Word’s Print Preview in the File menu and clicking the “Shrink to Fit” or “Shrink One Page” button.
lead_paragraph: Hate those printed Word documents that have a few lines spilling over onto the last page? You can save paper by going to Word’s Print Preview in the File menu and clicking the “Shrink to Fit” or “Shrink One Page” button, which has an icon showing multiple pages transforming onto one page. Word will automatically fiddle with the document’s text size and spacing to get it all on a single page. But if the shrinkage messes up your formatting or looks too cramped, undo it by pressing Control-Z (Command-Z on a Mac), which reverses the process.

headline.main: Tip of the Week: Thinking Green When You Print

abstract: The talks are dead. Really, this time they are dead.
lead_paragraph: The talks are dead. Really, this time they are dead.

headline.main: Yahoo Picks Google Deal Over Microsoft

abstract: Yahoo has ended all talks with Microsoft about a potential transaction. While that’s bad news for Carl Icahn and friends, Yahoo’s decision not to split the company and sell the search advertising piece to Microsoft makes a lot of sense.
snippet: Yahoo has ended all talks with Microsoft about a potential transaction. While that’s bad news for Carl Icahn and friends, Yahoo’s decision not to split the company and sell the search advertising piece to Microsoft makes a lot of sense.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft and Yahoo have broken up again — and this time, they say the relationship is over. In a news release Thursday afternoon, Yahoo said it had “concluded” discussions about a “potential transaction” with Microsoft for a full or partial acquisition.

headline.main: Yahoo Decides Not to Split Its Ad Baby in Two
